results:
Based on the search results, I found several sources related to Polish literary criticism and academic reception of Charlotte Brontë's "Jane Eyre." Here's what the search revealed:

## Polish Reception and Academic Studies of "Jane Eyre"

The search results show that Polish readers until recently could only access part of the Brontë sisters' works (frequently republished "Dziwne losy Jane Eyre" and "Villette" by Charlotte Brontë, and "Wichrowe Wzgórza" by Emily Brontë), but their work is currently experiencing a true renaissance in Poland.

### Academic Research and Publications

In recent years, remaining novels by Charlotte were published ("Shirley" in 2011, and "Profesor" a year later), as well as prose by Anne Brontë - the third writing sister, previously unknown to Polish readers. The publication of these books gives Polish literary scholars the opportunity for a new reading of the work of these excellent English writers.

An interesting attempt at such analysis was undertaken by Eryk Ostrowski in "Charlotte Brontë i jej siostrach śpiących", indicating active Polish academic engagement with Brontë scholarship.

### Editorial Work and Academic Commentary

The Polish edition includes scholarly apparatus with "editorial work and annotations by: Paulina Choromańska, Danuta Pustówka, Elżbieta Sekuła", demonstrating serious academic treatment of the work.

A new edition of "Villette" was published "with an introduction by Eryk Ostrowski," though it doesn't constitute as significant a cultural event in Poland as the publication of Anne Brontë's books.

### Critical Analysis in Polish Scholarship

The search results indicate that Polish literary criticism examines various aspects of the novel, including serious themes such as "relations between men and women, women's equality, treatment of children and women, religious faith and religious hypocrisy, self-realization and the nature of true love".

Polish critics also engage with the autobiographical elements in Charlotte Brontë's novels, noting that "Jane Eyre" in its first edition was even subtitled "autobiography" and that Brontë accurately described her own difficult experiences at Cowan Bridge school and her sister Maria who died of tuberculosis.

The materials show that Polish academic reception treats "Jane Eyre" as both a significant literary work and an important feminist text, with the novel being "recognized as the first feminist novel in history" in Polish literary discourse.
